passage.text: Peptide binding characteristics of the non-classical class Ib MHC molecule HLA-E assessed by a recombinant random peptide approach

The specificity of HLA-E is possibly not as exquisite as previously thought because it appears to refold around a random peptide library in comparison to the results obtained with classical class Ia MHC molecules, namely RT1-A1c and RAu, and can associate with synthetic peptides carrying an HIV sequence, suggesting that it could bind different phenotypes and present them to T lymphocytes.

During replication, Hepadnaviruses use reverse transcription of pregenomic RNA molecules. The viral viruses initiate replication by interacting with the viral reverse transcriptase (P) and using a primer to bind to the 5' copy of before starting DNA synthesis.

Using our knowledge of the cloning of mouse (RPTP) cDNA, the genomic structure and alternative splicing techniques of human genes, and of an 8 kb 3'UTR in human(P)-ATP complex, we propose that the largest known non-human RPTM gene, extending over 1 megabase pairs of genomic DNA, is due to expanded introns in the extracellular region; the protein domains of Peptides are encoded by modules that are flanked only by phase 0, and also by other two additional from
